qas.question: Where in Eritrea did Italian scientists find one of the oldest hominids?
How old was the hominid that was found in Eritrea?
What place in Eritrea is believed to have played a major part in human evolution?
What possible link is represented by the hominid found in Eritrea?

answers.text: hominids and the earliest anatomically modern humans

qas.question: What is the importance pertaining to the age of the hominid that was found in Eritrea?

answers.text: it is the oldest skeletal find of its kind

qas.question: What did German scientists find in Eritrea?
How old was the newest archaic Homo sapiens skeleton found in Eretria?
Where in Eritrea is it believed that no traces of evolution to anatomically modern humans will ever be found?
How far back can anatomically modern human bones be found?
How far back do scientists think archaic Homo sapiens transitioned to anatomically modern humans?

context: At <a0_0>Buya<a0_0/> in Eritrea, one of the oldest hominids representing a possible link between Homo erectus and an archaic <b5_0>Homo sapiens<b5_0/> was found by Italian scientists. Dated to <a1_0>over <b6_0><b8_0><b9_0>1 million years<b9_0/><b8_0/><a1_0/> old<b6_0/>, <a4_0>it is the oldest skeletal find of its kind<a4_0/> and provides a link between <a3_0>hominids and the earliest anatomically modern humans<a3_0/>. It is believed that the <a2_0>section of the <b7_0>Danakil Depression<b7_0/><a2_0/> in Eritrea was also a major player in terms of human evolution, and may contain other traces of evolution from Homo erectus hominids to anatomically modern humans.
